bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, August 29, 1950

div1.p: Siler believes that the project to publicize Reed's work, proposed by Sidney Wallach, would be a waste of money and only benefit Wallach's company. Siler informs Hench that Kean has been ill.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, August 29, 1950
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
August 29, 1950.
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p: Thanks very much for your note of August 19.

I have delayed having the photograph made showing the memorial tablet at
Ft. McNair until the grass lawn adjacent to it had time to grow. I expect to go
down again within the next few days and if conditions ppear to be suitable, will
have the photo made after which it is my intention to send one copy to each mem-
ber of the Board and retian one copy for the files of the Association.

Referring to your note concerning a letter from Mr. Wallach, I am just in
receipt of a letter from him under date of August 28 in which he advises me that
the joint Congressional resolution introduced several months ago is now a dead
issue because of the death of Representative Bland of Virginia. Mr. Wallach still
feels that a national or perhaps world-wide program concerning the work of Walter
Reed would be very highly desirable and he feels that it would be possible to work
out such a program and secure the financial aid to cover it, this to be carried
out under the auspices of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. He further asks
if it would be possible for him to meet formally the authorized officers of the
Association to consider arrangements for such a program.

As a matter of fact, I have always felt myself that this Mr. Wallach was
interested in this matter primarily because it would be possible for his company
to carry out and therefore profit financially from such a project. It has always
seemed to me that the idea of spending $350,000 during the next three years as
was contemplated by the resolution mentioned above would be a useless waste of
money and that if this money could be devoted to research work rather than publi-
city to commemorate Walter Reed's work it would be so much more highly desirable.

I do not know whether you know it or not but General Kean has been in
hospital for the past week or ten days suffering from retention because of an
enlarged prostate. I have seen him on two or three occasions add he is in fine
shape but drainage of the bladder has to be accomplished by constant use of a
catheter. Col. Kimborough is away for a few days but he told me before he left
that the only permanent relief would be removal of the prostate. I know that
before undertaking its removal, Col. Kimborough will have General Kean gone over
very carefully by the heads of the various divisions at Walter Reed Hospital,
noting particularly of course the condition of General Kean's heart.

As you know, he had his ninetieth birthday recently. We had the pleasure
of going out to see him on that day and wishing him many happy returns. He was
in very fine condition at that time. I will, of course, keep closely in touch
with his condition and will advise you concerning the steps that Col. Kimborough
proposes to take.
With most cordial regards, I am
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, J. F. Siler
Col., (MC), U.S.A., Ret'd jfa k
